content: Bishop of Singapore from 1966 to 1981 **Joshua Chiu Ban It** (周万一; 1918 – 9 November 2016) was the [Bishop of Singapore](/wiki/Bishop_of_Singapore) from 1966 to 1981, and was the first indigenous Bishop of Singapore. Chiu was born in 1918. He graduated with a [Bachelor of Laws](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Laws) from the [University of London](/wiki/University_of_London) in 1941 and after a period of study at [Westcott House, Cambridge](/wiki/Westcott_House,_Cambridge) in 1943, was ordained deacon in 1945 and priest in 1946. His first post was as [Curate](/wiki/Curate) at [St Francis, Bournville](/wiki/St_Francis_of_Assisi%27s_Church,_Bournville) after which he was [Priest in charge](/wiki/Priest_in_charge) of St Hilda, [Katong](/wiki/Katong). and then [Vicar](/wiki/Vicar) of [Selangor](/wiki/Selangor). From 1959 to 1961, Chiu was Home Secretary of the [Australian Board of Missions](/wiki/Australian_Board_of_Missions) and from then, until his elevation to the [episcopate](/wiki/Episcopate), held a similar post with the [World Council of Churches](/wiki/World_Council_of_Churches) as Secretary of Laymen. - Portrait [Church of England titles](/wiki/Church_of_England)Preceded by[Cyril Kenneth Sansbury](/wiki/Cyril_Kenneth_Sansbury) **[Bishop of Singapore](/wiki/Bishop_of_Singapore)** 1966 – 1981Succeeded by[Moses Tay Leng Kong](/wiki/Moses_Tay_Leng_Kong) ## Notes This article about an [Anglican](/wiki/Anglican) [bishop](/wiki/Bishop) is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e This Singaporean biographical article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Chiu Ban It
